Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Water Quality and Climate Change Adaptation to Extreme Precipitation Events

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Given the likelihood that climate change will result in changes to the hydrologic cycle, it is important to understand how extreme precipitation events may affect water systems. This project will analyze how biophysical and socioeconomic elements of the landscape affect water quality and the adaptability of water systems to extreme precipitation events, to understand water resource sustainability under stress. Climate change scenarios suggest more frequent extreme precipitation events and extended droughts, increasing the effect of contaminants on streams and underground aquifers. These events may also affect the resilience of social institutions and built structures that are necessary for water quality management and water distribution. This research will specifically address two central questions about changes in precipitation: first, how the spatial distribution and composition of land cover and land use in a watershed affects water quality when a region is exposed to extreme precipitation events, and second, which aspects of water governance promote sustainable, reliable sources of clean water in the region. The research will be carried out in the La Plata Watershed in Puerto Rico, which has been exposed to large precipitation extremes from multiple hurricanes and displays a diversity of water management systems. By reconstructing the history of land cover change, stream water quality, water governance, and extreme precipitation events in the La Plata Watershed, this project will produce models that explain the primary factors that affect water quality and sustainability. The field site is close to the University of Puerto Rico in Cayey, which will allow the field research methods and the knowledge obtained from this project to be integrated into an undergraduate science curriculum. Implementing and assessing new student-centered education course components based on this field research will lead to new strategies to integrate research into education and bolster student engagement in science.

The project will give new insights into how changes in land cover, precipitation events and water management affect water quality and sustainability. Understanding these processes is needed to address the complex human-environmental dynamics that are characteristic of climate change problems. By demonstrating which social and environmental factors enhance water quality and sustainable access to potable water, these results may impact water policies and help define better water resource management strategies that can adapt to climate change. Planned community interactions will create awareness about the collection of scientific data, local water quality issues, and the impact of geography on clean, sustainable water. Finally, the project will enhance science education by integrating field research experience and training in spatial thinking into undergraduate courses at a minority serving institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was designed to reveal the dynamics of water quality and access in a region experiencing extreme precipitation events.  It measured how different factors, specifically land cover, land use, and water management strategies, influence water quality within the La Plata Watershed in Puerto Rico, which is a watershed frequently exposed to hurricane and drought events and with a variety of land uses and water management systems.  The project focused on two main questions: first, how the spatial arrangement of landscape features within a watershed relates to water quality at varying precipitation conditions, and second, which aspects of water governance affect access to water and available water quality under varied climate conditions.

The research to answer the question of how land use within a watershed relates to water quality led to significant conclusions for both scientific research and policy about how to assess water quality in a tropical watershed, which we published in the Journal of Water and Health (2016). One important aspect of water quality is the microbial dynamics, since fecal contamination can lead to pathogens in water sources.  Not surprisingly, we found that increased urbanization and increased precipitation did lead to higher levels of downstream contamination, as measured by several indicators of water quality. However, some fecal indicator bacteria such as E. coli were also prevalent in pristine, non-urbanized catchements. We concluded that E. coli presence was not a good predictor of human fecal contamination or pathogen risk, and thus both understanding the land use in the watershed and using alternative, rapid tests for contamination (enterophages and coliphages) can improve how water quality in the tropics is assessed.

The research activities focused on the social aspects of water governance and how they relate to water quality led to significant conclusions for water policy. By observing different water management systems in La Plata, some of which are small surface or groundwater systems managed by community volunteers, we discovered that water quality has dimensions for water consumers that are often neglected.  Interviews and oral histories with water managers revealed how access, autonomy, resilience, sustainability, and environmental stewardship are key components of water resources that are rarely measured or acknowledged in policy-making.  We published these findings in The Palgrave Handbook of Critical Physical Geography (2018).  Hurricane María brought unprecedented precipitation as well as infrastructure damage to the study region, and during the aftermath of the event, these invisible aspects of water quality came to the forefront. Their importance is discussed in Alternautas (2019), and they are increasingly acknowledged by policymakers.

 Another key project objective was enhancing education and scientific outreach. The project aimed to use the opportunity provided by a field research site near the University of Puerto Rico at Cayey to enhance the research component of undergraduate education at the university, and thus to strengthen the future spatial sciences workforce by engaging diverse students in field research and geospatial analysis. Notably, students in the project participated in educating the broader community about water quality and land use change in Puerto Rico, helping to create two exhibits of geographic data generated by the project. The second of these, geo/visual/isla, introduced geographic techniques and concepts to thousands of people, including secondary-school students. These exhibits blended science and art to explore new methods of both engaging student researchers and informing the general public about landscape history and dynamics, which we described in the Journal of Land Use Science (2016) andAbstracts of the ICA (2019).  The project also expanded the curriculumat UPR-Cayey with new research based courses, and ultimately had significant impact on the pipeline of students from UPR-Cayey entering higher education in stem fields, including Ph.D. programs in geography and other fields.
